metadata.case_name: Assessee v. State of Uttar Pradesh
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeal No. 2300 to 2302 of 1969 and 14-15 of 1970

facts.text: The assessee is a registered dealer under the U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948, carrying on business at Kanpur in hydrogenated oil and washing soap, and imports and distributes vanaspati as an agent of Malwa Vanaspati and Chemical Company Ltd., Indore.
For assessment year 1957-58, assessee's return disclosed gross and net turnover of Rs. 1,66,387.03 P. and paid Rs. 1,060.30 P. towards tax.
Before assessing authority, assessee admitted tax liability of Rs. 10,339.19 P. and that it had collected this amount from purchasers.
Sales Tax Officer estimated total turnover at Rs. 58,06,132.30 P. after enquiries.
Assessee given 30 adjournments to rebut estimate but did not take advantage.
On 24th March 1962, assessee absent, applied for 15-day adjournment which was denied as assessment would be time-barred by end of 1961-62 financial year.
Assessing authority made best judgment assessment: turnover Rs. 58,06,132.30 P., tax liability Rs. 3,62,691.62 P. under Section 3A.
Assessee filed appeal within 30 days, deposited Rs. 1,600.
Appellate office raised objections to maintainability; after explanation, appeal entertained and notice issued.
Sales Tax Officer objected to maintainability under proviso to Section 9 for non-compliance; appeal dismissed as not maintainable.
At instance of assessee, questions referred to High Court (Sales Tax Reference No. 574 of 1963, Special Appeal No. 330 of 1963, etc.).
Assessee filed writ petition under Article 226 challenging validity of notification under Section 3A; dismissed.
Assessee filed application under Article 227 challenging recovery proceedings; dismissed.
Division Bench of Allahabad High Court held appeal properly dismissed (judgments dated August 7, 1968 and August 18, 1969).
Assessee bound under Rule 41(2) read with Rule 12 to submit quarterly returns and deposit tax calculated thereon.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appeal was illegally dismissed for non-compliance with proviso to Section 9(1) of the Act.
Whether the assessee, being an importer, can be considered as one of the successive dealers in the series of sales as contemplated by Section 3A.
Whether the notification issued under Section 3A was ultra vires the power granted to the government.

petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Proviso to Section 9(1); Ghanshyam Dass Balmukund vs. State of UP; United Timber Cashew Products P Ltd. vs. STO

petitioner_arguments.text: Assessee-appellant being an importer cannot be considered as one of the successive dealers in the series of sales as contemplated by Section 3A.
The notification issued under Section 3A was ultra vires the power granted to the government.
Whatever admissions made in return or before assessing authority, assessee can take different stand in memorandum of appeal; relevant is stand in appeal for Section 9 proviso.

respondent_arguments.text: Appeal not maintainable as proviso to Section 9 not complied with; no satisfactory proof of payment of admitted tax.

court_reasoning.text: Importer is the first dealer in the State and thus one of the successive dealers in the series; chain begins from first dealer.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Any one of the dealers in this chain can be considered as a successive dealer.

court_reasoning.text: Notification under Section 3A valid as it applies to importer.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Section 3A permits single-point levy on specified point in series of sales by successive dealers.

court_reasoning.text: Admissions in return and before assessing authority binding; assessee cannot change stand in appeal to make it maintainable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Expression 'tax admitted' in proviso to Section 9(1) refers to admission before assessing authority, not in appeal memorandum.

court_reasoning.text: Interpreting 'tax admitted' as in appeal would make Section 9 otiose; words 'or such instalments thereof as may become payable' indicate admission before assessing authority under Rule 41(2).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No interpretation should make provision otiose.

court_reasoning.text: Stand in appeal that assessee not within Section 3A was afterthought; no such contention before assessing authority.
Distinguished Ghanshyam Dass Balmukund and United Timber Cashew Products.

holdings.text: Importer is one of the successive dealers under Section 3A.
Proviso to Section 9(1) requires payment of tax admitted before assessing authority; appeal properly dismissed as not maintainable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Kumar Rajendra Swaroop vs. Commissioner of Sales Tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Importer is one of the successive dealers.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ghanshyam Dass Balmukund vs. The State of Uttar Pradesh Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Held that admission in appeal memorandum suffices for Section 9 proviso; rejected.

precedents_cited.case_name: United Timber Cashew Products P Ltd. vs. Sales Tax Officer, Cannanore
precedents_cited.relevance: Followed Allahabad HC view on admission in appeal; rejected.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: General multi-point tax under Sec 3; single-point levy under Sec 3A; appeal maintainability under Sec 9 proviso requiring payment of admitted tax.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Sales Tax Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Quarterly returns by importer (R.12); deposit tax with return (R.41(2)).

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petitions challenging notification and recovery dismissed.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court rejected all contentions of the assessee-appellant, upheld the dismissal of the appeal by appellate authority and High Court decisions, confirming the assessment under Section 3A and non-maintainability of appeal for non-payment of admitted tax.

key_quotes.text: "Undoubtedly, an importer is one of the dealers. He is the first dealer in the State. The chain of successive dealers begins from the first dealer and it goes upto the last dealer. Any one of the dealers in this chain can be considered as a successive dealer."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines 'successive dealers' under Section 3A including importer.

key_quotes.text: "If we come to the conclusion that the expression 'tax admitted' in the proviso to Section 9(1) means that admitted in the memorandum of appeal, section 9 can be made wholly useless."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects interpretation allowing change of admission in appeal.

key_quotes.text: "Ordinarily no interpretation should be placed on a provision which would have the effect of making the provision either otiose or a dead letter."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle of statutory interpretation applied to Section 9 proviso.
